lines.text: Enter the PRINCESS, KATHARINE, ROSALINE, and MARIA

lines.speaker: princess
lines.text: Sweet hearts, we shall be rich ere we depart, If fairings come thus plentifully in: A lady walld about with diamonds! Look you what I have from the loving king.

lines.speaker: rosaline
lines.text: Madame, came nothing else along with that

lines.speaker: princess
lines.text: Nothing but this! yes, as much love in rhyme As would be crammd up in a sheet of paper, Writ o both sides the leaf, margent and all, That he was fain to seal on Cupids name.

lines.speaker: rosaline
lines.text: That was the way to make his godhead wax, For he hath been five thousand years a boy.

lines.speaker: katharine
lines.text: Ay, and a shrewd unhappy gallows too.

lines.speaker: rosaline
lines.text: Youll neer be friends with him a killd your sister.

lines.speaker: katharine
lines.text: He made her melancholy, sad, and heavy And so she died: had she been light, like you, Of such a merry, nimble, stirring spirit, She might ha been a grandam ere she died: And so may you for a light heart lives long.

lines.speaker: rosaline
lines.text: Whats your dark meaning, mouse, of this light word

lines.speaker: katharine
lines.text: A light condition in a beauty dark.

lines.speaker: rosaline
lines.text: We need more light to find your meaning out.

lines.speaker: katharine
lines.text: Youll mar the light by taking it in snuff Therefore Ill darkly end the argument.

lines.speaker: rosaline
lines.text: Look what you do, you do it still i the dark.

lines.speaker: katharine
lines.text: So do not you, for you are a light wench.

lines.speaker: rosaline
lines.text: Indeed I weigh not you, and therefore light.

lines.speaker: katharine
lines.text: You weigh me not O, thats you care not for me.

lines.speaker: rosaline
lines.text: Great reason for past cure is still past care.

lines.speaker: princess
lines.text: Well bandied both a set of wit well playd. But Rosaline, you have a favour too: Who sent it and what is it

lines.speaker: rosaline
lines.text: I would you knew: An if my face were but as fair as yours, My favour were as great be witness this. Nay, I have verses too, I thank Biron: The numbers true and, were the numbering too, I were the fairest goddess on the ground: I am compared to twenty thousand fairs. O, he hath drawn my picture in his letter!

lines.speaker: princess
lines.text: Any thing like

lines.speaker: rosaline
lines.text: Much in the letters nothing in the praise.

lines.speaker: princess
lines.text: Beauteous as ink a good conclusion.

lines.speaker: katharine
lines.text: Fair as a text B in a copybook.

lines.speaker: rosaline
lines.text: Ware pencils, ho! let me not die your debtor, My red dominical, my golden letter: O, that your face were not so full of Os!

lines.speaker: katharine
lines.text: A pox of that jest! and I beshrew all shrows.

lines.speaker: princess
lines.text: But, Katharine, what was sent to you from fair Dumain

lines.speaker: katharine
lines.text: Madam, this glove.

lines.speaker: princess
lines.text: Did he not send you twain

lines.speaker: katharine
lines.text: Yes, madam, and moreover Some thousand verses of a faithful lover, A huge translation of hypocrisy, Vilely compiled, profound simplicity.

lines.speaker: maria
lines.text: This and these pearls to me sent Longaville: The letter is too long by half a mile.

lines.speaker: princess
lines.text: I think no less. Dost thou not wish in heart The chain were longer and the letter short

lines.speaker: maria
lines.text: Ay, or I would these hands might never part.

lines.speaker: princess
lines.text: We are wise girls to mock our lovers so.

lines.speaker: rosaline
lines.text: They are worse fools to purchase mocking so. That same Biron Ill torture ere I go: O that I knew he were but in by the week! How I would make him fawn and beg and seek And wait the season and observe the times And spend his prodigal wits in bootless rhymes And shape his service wholly to my hests And make him proud to make me proud that jests! So perttauntlike would I oersway his state That he should be my fool and I his fate.

lines.speaker: princess
lines.text: None are so surely caught, when they are catchd, As wit turnd fool: folly, in wisdom hatchd, Hath wisdoms warrant and the help of school And wits own grace to grace a learned fool.

lines.speaker: rosaline
lines.text: The blood of youth burns not with such excess As gravitys revolt to wantonness.

lines.speaker: maria
lines.text: Folly in fools bears not so strong a note As foolery in the wise, when wit doth dote Since all the power thereof it doth apply To prove, by wit, worth in simplicity.

lines.speaker: princess
lines.text: Here comes Boyet, and mirth is in his face.
Enter BOYET

lines.speaker: boyet
lines.text: O, I am stabbd with laughter! Wheres her grace

lines.speaker: princess
lines.text: Thy news Boyet

lines.speaker: boyet
lines.text: Prepare, madam, prepare! Arm, wenches, arm! encounters mounted are Against your peace: Love doth approach disguised, Armed in arguments youll be surprised: Muster your wits stand in your own defence Or hide your heads like cowards, and fly hence.

lines.speaker: princess
lines.text: Saint Denis to Saint Cupid! What are they That charge their breath against us say, scout, say.

lines.speaker: boyet
lines.text: Under the cool shade of a sycamore I thought to close mine eyes some half an hour When, lo! to interrupt my purposed rest, Toward that shade I might behold addrest The king and his companions: warily I stole into a neighbour thicket by, And overheard what you shall overhear, That, by and by, disguised they will be here. Their herald is a pretty knavish page, That well by heart hath connd his embassage: Action and accent did they teach him there Thus must thou speak, and thus thy body bear: And ever and anon they made a doubt Presence majestical would put him out, For, quoth the king, an angel shalt thou see Yet fear not thou, but speak audaciously. The boy replied, An angel is not evil I should have feard her had she been a devil. With that, all laughd and clappd him on the shoulder, Making the bold wag by their praises bolder: One rubbd his elbow thus, and fleerd and swore A better speech was never spoke before Another, with his finger and his thumb, Cried, Via! we will dot, come what will come The third he caperd, and cried, All goes well The fourth turnd on the toe, and down he fell. With that, they all did tumble on the ground, With such a zealous laughter, so profound, That in this spleen ridiculous appears, To cheque their folly, passions solemn tears.

lines.speaker: princess
lines.text: But what, but what, come they to visit us

lines.speaker: boyet
lines.text: They do, they do: and are apparelld thus. Like Muscovites or Russians, as I guess. Their purpose is to parle, to court and dance And every one his lovefeat will advance Unto his several mistress, which theyll know By favours several which they did bestow.

lines.speaker: princess
lines.text: And will they so the gallants shall be taskd For, ladies, we shall every one be maskd And not a man of them shall have the grace, Despite of suit, to see a ladys face. Hold, Rosaline, this favour thou shalt wear, And then the king will court thee for his dear Hold, take thou this, my sweet, and give me thine, So shall Biron take me for Rosaline. And change your favours too so shall your loves Woo contrary, deceived by these removes.

lines.speaker: rosaline
lines.text: Come on, then wear the favours most in sight.

lines.speaker: katharine
lines.text: But in this changing what is your intent

lines.speaker: princess
lines.text: The effect of my intent is to cross theirs: They do it but in mocking merriment And mock for mock is only my intent. Their several counsels they unbosom shall To loves mistook, and so be mockd withal Upon the next occasion that we meet, With visages displayed, to talk and greet.

lines.speaker: rosaline
lines.text: But shall we dance, if they desire tot

lines.speaker: princess
lines.text: No, to the death, we will not move a foot Nor to their pennd speech render we no grace, But while tis spoke each turn away her face.

lines.speaker: boyet
lines.text: Why, that contempt will kill the speakers heart, And quite divorce his memory from his part.

lines.speaker: princess
lines.text: Therefore I do it and I make no doubt The rest will neer come in, if he be out Theres no such sport as sport by sport oerthrown, To make theirs ours and ours none but our own: So shall we stay, mocking intended game, And they, well mockd, depart away with shame.
Trumpets sound within

lines.speaker: boyet
lines.text: The trumpet sounds: be maskd the maskers come.
The Ladies mask
Enter Blackamoors with music MOTH FERDINAND,  BIRON, LONGAVILLE, and DUMAIN, in Russian habits, and masked

lines.speaker: moth
lines.text: All hail, the richest beauties on the earth!

lines.speaker: boyet
lines.text: Beauties no richer than rich taffeta.

lines.speaker: moth
lines.text: A holy parcel of the fairest dames. That ever turnd theirbacksto mortal views!
The Ladies turn their backs to him

lines.speaker: biron
lines.text: [Aside to MOTH]  Their eyes, villain, their eyes!

lines.speaker: moth
lines.text: That ever turnd their eyes to mortal views!Out

lines.speaker: boyet
lines.text: True out indeed.

lines.speaker: moth
lines.text: Out of your favours, heavenly spirits, vouchsafe Not to behold

lines.speaker: biron
lines.text: [Aside to MOTH]  Once to behold, rogue.

lines.speaker: moth
lines.text: Once to behold with your sunbeamed eyes, with your sunbeamed eyes

lines.speaker: boyet
lines.text: They will not answer to that epithet You were best call it daughterbeamed eyes.

lines.speaker: moth
lines.text: They do not mark me, and that brings me out.

lines.speaker: biron
lines.text: Is this your perfectness be gone, you rogue!
Exit MOTH

lines.speaker: rosaline
lines.text: What would these strangers know their minds, Boyet: If they do speak our language, tis our will: That some plain man recount their purposes Know what they would.

lines.speaker: boyet
lines.text: What would you with the princess

lines.speaker: biron
lines.text: Nothing but peace and gentle visitation.

lines.speaker: rosaline
lines.text: What would they, say they

lines.speaker: boyet
lines.text: Nothing but peace and gentle visitation.

lines.speaker: rosaline
lines.text: Why, that they have and bid them so be gone.

lines.speaker: boyet
lines.text: She says, you have it, and you may be gone.

lines.speaker: ferdinand
lines.text: Say to her, we have measured many miles To tread a measure with her on this grass.

lines.speaker: boyet
lines.text: They say, that they have measured many a mile To tread a measure with you on this grass.

lines.speaker: rosaline
lines.text: It is not so. Ask them how many inches Is in one mile: if they have measured many, The measure then of one is easily told.

lines.speaker: boyet
lines.text: If to come hither you have measured miles, And many miles, the princess bids you tell How many inches doth fill up one mile.

lines.speaker: biron
lines.text: Tell her, we measure them by weary steps.

lines.speaker: boyet
lines.text: She hears herself.

lines.speaker: rosaline
lines.text: How many weary steps, Of many weary miles you have oergone, Are numberd in the travel of one mile

lines.speaker: biron
lines.text: We number nothing that we spend for you: Our duty is so rich, so infinite, That we may do it still without accompt. Vouchsafe to show the sunshine of your face, That we, like savages, may worship it.

lines.speaker: rosaline
lines.text: My face is but a moon, and clouded too.

lines.speaker: ferdinand
lines.text: Blessed are clouds, to do as such clouds do! Vouchsafe, bright moon, and these thy stars, to shine, Those clouds removed, upon our watery eyne.

lines.speaker: rosaline
lines.text: O vain petitioner! beg a greater matter Thou now requestst but moonshine in the water.

lines.speaker: ferdinand
lines.text: Then, in our measure do but vouchsafe one change. Thou bidst me beg: this begging is not strange.

lines.speaker: rosaline
lines.text: Play, music, then! Nay, you must do it soon. Not yet! no dance! Thus change I like the moon.
Music plays

lines.speaker: ferdinand
lines.text: Will you not dance How come you thus estranged

lines.speaker: rosaline
lines.text: You took the moon at full, but now shes changed.

lines.speaker: ferdinand
lines.text: Yet still she is the moon, and I the man. The music plays vouchsafe some motion to it.

lines.speaker: rosaline
lines.text: Our ears vouchsafe it.

lines.speaker: ferdinand
lines.text: But your legs should do it.

lines.speaker: rosaline
lines.text: Since you are strangers and come here by chance, Well not be nice: take hands. We will not dance.

lines.speaker: ferdinand
lines.text: Why take we hands, then

lines.speaker: rosaline
lines.text: Only to part friends: Curtsy, sweet hearts and so the measure ends.

lines.speaker: ferdinand
lines.text: More measure of this measure be not nice.

lines.speaker: rosaline
lines.text: We can afford no more at such a price.

lines.speaker: ferdinand
lines.text: Prize you yourselves: what buys your company

lines.speaker: rosaline
lines.text: Your absence only.

lines.speaker: ferdinand
lines.text: That can never be.

lines.speaker: rosaline
lines.text: Then cannot we be bought: and so, adieu Twice to your visor, and half once to you.

lines.speaker: ferdinand
lines.text: If you deny to dance, lets hold more chat.

lines.speaker: rosaline
lines.text: In private, then.

lines.speaker: ferdinand
lines.text: I am best pleased with that.
They converse apart

lines.speaker: biron
lines.text: Whitehanded mistress, one sweet word with thee.

lines.speaker: princess
lines.text: Honey, and milk, and sugar there is three.

lines.speaker: biron
lines.text: Nay then, two treys, and if you grow so nice, Metheglin, wort, and malmsey: well run, dice! Theres halfadozen sweets.

lines.speaker: princess
lines.text: Seventh sweet, adieu: Since you can cog, Ill play no more with you.

lines.speaker: biron
lines.text: One word in secret.

lines.speaker: princess
lines.text: Let it not be sweet.

lines.speaker: biron
lines.text: Thou grievest my gall.

lines.speaker: princess
lines.text: Gall! bitter.

lines.speaker: biron
lines.text: Therefore meet.
They converse apart

lines.speaker: dumain
lines.text: Will you vouchsafe with me to change a word

lines.speaker: maria
lines.text: Name it.

lines.speaker: dumain
lines.text: Fair lady,

lines.speaker: maria
lines.text: Say you so Fair lord, Take that for your fair lady.

lines.speaker: dumain
lines.text: Please it you, As much in private, and Ill bid adieu.
They converse apart

lines.speaker: katharine
lines.text: What, was your vizard made without a tongue

lines.speaker: longaville
lines.text: I know the reason, lady, why you ask.

lines.speaker: katharine
lines.text: O for your reason! quickly, sir I long.

lines.speaker: longaville
lines.text: You have a double tongue within your mask, And would afford my speechless vizard half.

lines.speaker: katharine
lines.text: Veal, quoth the Dutchman. Is not veal a calf

lines.speaker: longaville
lines.text: A calf, fair lady!

lines.speaker: katharine
lines.text: No, a fair lord calf.

lines.speaker: longaville
lines.text: Lets part the word.

lines.speaker: katharine
lines.text: No, Ill not be your half Take all, and wean it it may prove an ox.

lines.speaker: longaville
lines.text: Look, how you butt yourself in these sharp mocks! Will you give horns, chaste lady do not so.

lines.speaker: katharine
lines.text: Then die a calf, before your horns do grow.

lines.speaker: longaville
lines.text: One word in private with you, ere I die.

lines.speaker: katharine
lines.text: Bleat softly then the butcher hears you cry.
They converse apart

lines.speaker: boyet
lines.text: The tongues of mocking wenches are as keen As is the razors edge invisible, Cutting a smaller hair than may be seen, Above the sense of sense so sensible Seemeth their conference their conceits have wings Fleeter than arrows, bullets, wind, thought, swifter things.

lines.speaker: rosaline
lines.text: Not one word more, my maids break off, break off.

lines.speaker: biron
lines.text: By heaven, all drybeaten with pure scoff!

lines.speaker: ferdinand
lines.text: Farewell, mad wenches you have simple wits.

lines.speaker: princess
lines.text: Twenty adieus, my frozen Muscovits. Are these the breed of wits so wonderd at
Exeunt FERDINAND, Lords, and Blackamoors

lines.speaker: boyet
lines.text: Tapers they are, with your sweet breaths puffd out.

lines.speaker: rosaline
lines.text: Wellliking wits they have gross, gross fat, fat.

lines.speaker: princess
lines.text: O poverty in wit, kinglypoor flout! Will they not, think you, hang themselves tonight Or ever, but in vizards, show their faces This pert Biron was out of countenance quite.

lines.speaker: rosaline
lines.text: O, they were all in lamentable cases! The king was weepingripe for a good word.

lines.speaker: princess
lines.text: Biron did swear himself out of all suit.

lines.speaker: maria
lines.text: Dumain was at my service, and his sword: No point, quoth I my servant straight was mute.

lines.speaker: katharine
lines.text: Lord Longaville said, I came oer his heart And trow you what he called me

lines.speaker: princess
lines.text: Qualm, perhaps.

lines.speaker: katharine
lines.text: Yes, in good faith.

lines.speaker: princess
lines.text: Go, sickness as thou art!

lines.speaker: rosaline
lines.text: Well, better wits have worn plain statutecaps. But will you hear the king is my love sworn.

lines.speaker: princess
lines.text: And quick Biron hath plighted faith to me.

lines.speaker: katharine
lines.text: And Longaville was for my service born.

lines.speaker: maria
lines.text: Dumain is mine, as sure as bark on tree.

lines.speaker: boyet
lines.text: Madam, and pretty mistresses, give ear: Immediately they will again be here In their own shapes for it can never be They will digest this harsh indignity.

lines.speaker: princess
lines.text: Will they return

lines.speaker: boyet
lines.text: They will, they will, God knows, And leap for joy, though they are lame with blows: Therefore change favours and, when they repair, Blow like sweet roses in this summer air.

lines.speaker: princess
lines.text: How blow how blow speak to be understood.

lines.speaker: boyet
lines.text: Fair ladies maskd are roses in their bud Dismaskd, their damask sweet commixture shown, Are angels vailing clouds, or roses blown.

lines.speaker: princess
lines.text: Avaunt, perplexity! What shall we do, If they return in their own shapes to woo

lines.speaker: rosaline
lines.text: Good madam, if by me youll be advised, Lets, mock them still, as well known as disguised: Let us complain to them what fools were here, Disguised like Muscovites, in shapeless gear And wonder what they were and to what end Their shallow shows and prologue vilely pennd And their rough carriage so ridiculous, Should be presented at our tent to us.

lines.speaker: boyet
lines.text: Ladies, withdraw: the gallants are at hand.

lines.speaker: princess
lines.text: Whip to our tents, as roes run oer land.
Exeunt PRINCESS, ROSALINE, KATHARINE, and MARIA
Reenter FERDINAND, BIRON, LONGAVILLE, and DUMAIN, in their proper habits

lines.speaker: ferdinand
lines.text: Fair sir, God save you! Wheres the princess

lines.speaker: boyet
lines.text: Gone to her tent. Please it your majesty Command me any service to her thither

lines.speaker: ferdinand
lines.text: That she vouchsafe me audience for one word.

lines.speaker: boyet
lines.text: I will and so will she, I know, my lord.
Exit

lines.speaker: biron
lines.text: This fellow pecks up wit as pigeons pease, And utters it again when God doth please: He is wits pedler, and retails his wares At wakes and wassails, meetings, markets, fairs And we that sell by gross, the Lord doth know, Have not the grace to grace it with such show. This gallant pins the wenches on his sleeve Had he been Adam, he had tempted Eve A can carve too, and lisp: why, this is he That kissd his hand away in courtesy This is the ape of form, monsieur the nice, That, when he plays at tables, chides the dice In honourable terms: nay, he can sing A mean most meanly and in ushering Mend him who can: the ladies call him sweet The stairs, as he treads on them, kiss his feet: This is the flower that smiles on every one, To show his teeth as white as whales bone And consciences, that will not die in debt, Pay him the due of honeytongued Boyet.

lines.speaker: ferdinand
lines.text: A blister on his sweet tongue, with my heart, That put Armados page out of his part!

lines.speaker: biron
lines.text: See where it comes! Behavior, what wert thou Till this madman showd thee and what art thou now
Reenter the PRINCESS, ushered by BOYET, ROSALINE, MARIA, and KATHARINE

lines.speaker: ferdinand
lines.text: All hail, sweet madam, and fair time of day!

lines.speaker: princess
lines.text: Fair in all hail is foul, as I conceive.

lines.speaker: ferdinand
lines.text: Construe my speeches better, if you may.

lines.speaker: princess
lines.text: Then wish me better I will give you leave.

lines.speaker: ferdinand
lines.text: We came to visit you, and purpose now To lead you to our court vouchsafe it then.

lines.speaker: princess
lines.text: This field shall hold me and so hold your vow: Nor God, nor I, delights in perjured men.

lines.speaker: ferdinand
lines.text: Rebuke me not for that which you provoke: The virtue of your eye must break my oath.

lines.speaker: princess
lines.text: You nickname virtue vice you should have spoke For virtues office never breaks mens troth. Now by my maiden honour, yet as pure As the unsullied lily, I protest, A world of torments though I should endure, I would not yield to be your houses guest So much I hate a breaking cause to be Of heavenly oaths, vowd with integrity.

lines.speaker: ferdinand
lines.text: O, you have lived in desolation here, Unseen, unvisited, much to our shame.

lines.speaker: princess
lines.text: Not so, my lord it is not so, I swear We have had pastimes here and pleasant game: A mess of Russians left us but of late.

lines.speaker: ferdinand
lines.text: How, madam! Russians!

lines.speaker: princess
lines.text: Ay, in truth, my lord Trim gallants, full of courtship and of state.

lines.speaker: rosaline
lines.text: Madam, speak true. It is not so, my lord: My lady, to the manner of the days, In courtesy gives undeserving praise. We four indeed confronted were with four In Russian habit: here they stayd an hour, And talkd apace and in that hour, my lord, They did not bless us with one happy word. I dare not call them fools but this I think, When they are thirsty, fools would fain have drink.

lines.speaker: biron
lines.text: This jest is dry to me. Fair gentle sweet, Your wit makes wise things foolish: when we greet, With eyes best seeing, heavens fiery eye, By light we lose light: your capacity Is of that nature that to your huge store Wise things seem foolish and rich things but poor.

lines.speaker: rosaline
lines.text: This proves you wise and rich, for in my eye,

lines.speaker: biron
lines.text: I am a fool, and full of poverty.

lines.speaker: rosaline
lines.text: But that you take what doth to you belong, It were a fault to snatch words from my tongue.

lines.speaker: biron
lines.text: O, I am yours, and all that I possess!

lines.speaker: rosaline
lines.text: All the fool mine

lines.speaker: biron
lines.text: I cannot give you less.

lines.speaker: rosaline
lines.text: Which of the vizards was it that you wore

lines.speaker: biron
lines.text: Where when what vizard why demand you this

lines.speaker: rosaline
lines.text: There, then, that vizard that superfluous case That hid the worse and showd the better face.

lines.speaker: ferdinand
lines.text: We are descried theyll mock us now downright.

lines.speaker: dumain
lines.text: Let us confess and turn it to a jest.

lines.speaker: princess
lines.text: Amazed, my lord why looks your highness sad

lines.speaker: rosaline
lines.text: Help, hold his brows! hell swoon! Why look you pale Seasick, I think, coming from Muscovy.

lines.speaker: biron
lines.text: Thus pour the stars down plagues for perjury. Can any face of brass hold longer out lady, dart thy skill at me Bruise me with scorn, confound me with a flout Thrust thy sharp wit quite through my ignorance Cut me to pieces with thy keen conceit And I will wish thee never more to dance, Nor never more in Russian habit wait. O, never will I trust to speeches pennd, Nor to the motion of a schoolboys tongue, Nor never come in vizard to my friend, Nor woo in rhyme, like a blind harpers song! Taffeta phrases, silken terms precise, Threepiled hyperboles, spruce affectation, Figures pedantical these summerflies Have blown me full of maggot ostentation: I do forswear them and I here protest, By this white glovehow white the hand, God knows! Henceforth my wooing mind shall be expressd In russet yeas and honest kersey noes: And, to begin, wench,so God help me, la! My love to thee is sound, sans crack or flaw.

lines.speaker: rosaline
lines.text: Sans sans, I pray you.

lines.speaker: biron
lines.text: Yet I have a trick Of the old rage: bear with me, I am sick Ill leave it by degrees. Soft, let us see: Write, Lord have mercy on us on those three They are infected in their hearts it lies They have the plague, and caught it of your eyes These lords are visited you are not free, For the Lords tokens on you do I see.

lines.speaker: princess
lines.text: No, they are free that gave these tokens to us.

lines.speaker: biron
lines.text: Our states are forfeit: seek not to undo us.

lines.speaker: rosaline
lines.text: It is not so for how can this be true, That you stand forfeit, being those that sue

lines.speaker: biron
lines.text: Peace! for I will not have to do with you.

lines.speaker: rosaline
lines.text: Nor shall not, if I do as I intend.

lines.speaker: biron
lines.text: Speak for yourselves my wit is at an end.

lines.speaker: ferdinand
lines.text: Teach us, sweet madam, for our rude transgression Some fair excuse.

lines.speaker: princess
lines.text: The fairest is confession. Were not you here but even now disguised

lines.speaker: ferdinand
lines.text: Madam, I was.

lines.speaker: princess
lines.text: And were you well advised

lines.speaker: ferdinand
lines.text: I was, fair madam.

lines.speaker: princess
lines.text: When you then were here, What did you whisper in your ladys ear

lines.speaker: ferdinand
lines.text: That more than all the world I did respect her.

lines.speaker: princess
lines.text: When she shall challenge this, you will reject her.

lines.speaker: ferdinand
lines.text: Upon mine honour, no.

lines.speaker: princess
lines.text: Peace, peace! forbear: Your oath once broke, you force not to forswear.

lines.speaker: ferdinand
lines.text: Despise me, when I break this oath of mine.

lines.speaker: princess
lines.text: I will: and therefore keep it. Rosaline, What did the Russian whisper in your ear

lines.speaker: rosaline
lines.text: Madam, he swore that he did hold me dear As precious eyesight, and did value me Above this world adding thereto moreover That he would wed me, or else die my lover.

lines.speaker: princess
lines.text: God give thee joy of him! the noble lord Most honourably doth unhold his word.

lines.speaker: ferdinand
lines.text: What mean you, madam by my life, my troth, I never swore this lady such an oath.

lines.speaker: rosaline
lines.text: By heaven, you did and to confirm it plain, You gave me this: but take it, sir, again.

lines.speaker: ferdinand
lines.text: My faith and this the princess I did give: I knew her by this jewel on her sleeve.

lines.speaker: princess
lines.text: Pardon me, sir, this jewel did she wear And Lord Biron, I thank him, is my dear. What, will you have me, or your pearl again

lines.speaker: biron
lines.text: Neither of either I remit both twain. I see the trick ont: here was a consent, Knowing aforehand of our merriment, To dash it like a Christmas comedy: Some carrytale, some pleaseman, some slight zany, Some mumblenews, some trencherknight, some Dick, That smiles his cheek in years and knows the trick To make my lady laugh when shes disposed, Told our intents before which once disclosed, The ladies did change favours: and then we, Following the signs, wood but the sign of she. Now, to our perjury to add more terror, We are again forsworn, in will and error. Much upon this it is: and might not you Forestall our sport, to make us thus untrue Do not you know my ladys foot by the squier, And laugh upon the apple of her eye And stand between her back, sir, and the fire, Holding a trencher, jesting merrily You put our page out: go, you are allowd Die when you will, a smock shall be your shroud. You leer upon me, do you theres an eye Wounds like a leaden sword.
To BOYET

lines.speaker: boyet
lines.text: Full merrily Hath this brave manage, this career, been run.

lines.speaker: biron
lines.text: Lo, he is tilting straight! Peace! I have done. Welcome, pure wit! thou partest a fair fray.
Enter COSTARD

lines.speaker: costard
lines.text: O Lord, sir, they would know Whether the three Worthies shall come in or no.

lines.speaker: biron
lines.text: What, are there but three

lines.speaker: costard
lines.text: No, sir but it is vara fine, For every one pursents three.

lines.speaker: biron
lines.text: And three times thrice is nine.

lines.speaker: costard
lines.text: Not so, sir under correction, sir I hope it is not so. You cannot beg us, sir, I can assure you, sir we know what we know: I hope, sir, three times thrice, sir,

lines.speaker: biron
lines.text: Is not nine.

lines.speaker: costard
lines.text: Under correction, sir, we know whereuntil it doth amount.

lines.speaker: biron
lines.text: By Jove, I always took three threes for nine.

lines.speaker: costard
lines.text: O Lord, sir, it were pity you should get your living by reckoning, sir.

lines.speaker: biron
lines.text: How much is it

lines.speaker: costard
lines.text: O Lord, sir, the parties themselves, the actors, sir, will show whereuntil it doth amount: for mine own part, I am, as they say, but to parfect one man in one poor man, Pompion the Great, sir.

lines.speaker: biron
lines.text: Art thou one of the Worthies

lines.speaker: costard
lines.text: It pleased them to think me worthy of Pompion the Great: for mine own part, I know not the degree of the Worthy, but I am to stand for him.

lines.speaker: biron
lines.text: Go, bid them prepare.

lines.speaker: costard
lines.text: We will turn it finely off, sir we will take some care.
Exit

lines.speaker: ferdinand
lines.text: Biron, they will shame us: let them not approach.

lines.speaker: biron
lines.text: We are shameproof, my lord: and tis some policy To have one show worse than the kings and his company.

lines.speaker: ferdinand
lines.text: I say they shall not come.

lines.speaker: princess
lines.text: Nay, my good lord, let me oerrule you now: That sport best pleases that doth least know how: Where zeal strives to content, and the contents Dies in the zeal of that which it presents: Their form confounded makes most form in mirth, When great things labouring perish in their birth.

lines.speaker: biron
lines.text: A right description of our sport, my lord. DON
Enter DON ADRIANO DE ARMADO

lines.speaker: adriano de armado
lines.text: Anointed, I implore so much expense of thy royal sweet breath as will utter a brace of words.
Converses apart with FERDINAND, and delivers him a paper

lines.speaker: princess
lines.text: Doth this man serve God

lines.speaker: biron
lines.text: Why ask you

lines.speaker: princess
lines.text: He speaks not like a man of Gods making. DON

lines.speaker: adriano de armado
lines.text: That is all one, my fair, sweet, honey monarch for, I protest, the schoolmaster is exceeding fantastical too, too vain, too too vain: but we will put it, as they say, to fortuna de la guerra. I wish you the peace of mind, most royal couplement!
Exit

lines.speaker: ferdinand
lines.text: Here is like to be a good presence of Worthies. He presents Hector of Troy the swain, Pompey the Great the parish curate, Alexander Armados page, Hercules the pedant, Judas Maccabaeus: And if these four Worthies in their first show thrive, These four will change habits, and present the other five.

lines.speaker: biron
lines.text: There is five in the first show.

lines.speaker: ferdinand
lines.text: You are deceived tis not so.

lines.speaker: biron
lines.text: The pedant, the braggart, the hedgepriest, the fool and the boy: Abate throw at novum, and the whole world again Cannot pick out five such, take each one in his vein.

lines.speaker: ferdinand
lines.text: The ship is under sail, and here she comes amain.
Enter COSTARD, for Pompey

lines.speaker: costard
lines.text: I Pompey am,

lines.speaker: boyet
lines.text: You lie, you are not he.

lines.speaker: costard
lines.text: I Pompey am,

lines.speaker: boyet
lines.text: With libbards head on knee.

lines.speaker: biron
lines.text: Well said, old mocker: I must needs be friends with thee.

lines.speaker: costard
lines.text: I Pompey am, Pompey surnamed the Big

lines.speaker: dumain
lines.text: The Great.

lines.speaker: costard
lines.text: It is, Great, sir: Pompey surnamed the Great That oft in field, with targe and shield, did make my foe to sweat: And travelling along this coast, I here am come by chance, And lay my arms before the legs of this sweet lass of France, If your ladyship would say, Thanks, Pompey, I had done.

lines.speaker: princess
lines.text: Great thanks, great Pompey.

lines.speaker: costard
lines.text: Tis not so much worth but I hope I was perfect: I made a little fault in Great.

lines.speaker: biron
lines.text: My hat to a halfpenny, Pompey proves the best Worthy.
Enter SIR NATHANIEL, for Alexander

lines.speaker: sir nathaniel
lines.text: When in the world I lived, I was the worlds commander By east, west, north, and south, I spread my conquering might: My scutcheon plain declares that I am Alisander,

lines.speaker: boyet
lines.text: Your nose says, no, you are not for it stands too right.

lines.speaker: biron
lines.text: Your nose smells no in this, most tendersmelling knight.

lines.speaker: princess
lines.text: The conqueror is dismayd. Proceed, good Alexander.

lines.speaker: sir nathaniel
lines.text: When in the world I lived, I was the worlds commander,

lines.speaker: boyet
lines.text: Most true, tis right you were so, Alisander.

lines.speaker: biron
lines.text: Pompey the Great,

lines.speaker: costard
lines.text: Your servant, and Costard.

lines.speaker: biron
lines.text: Take away the conqueror, take away Alisander.

lines.speaker: costard
lines.text: [To SIR NATHANIEL]  O, sir, you have overthrown Alisander the conqueror! You will be scraped out of the painted cloth for this: your lion, that holds his pollaxe sitting on a closestool, will be given to Ajax: he will be the ninth Worthy. A conqueror, and afeard to speak! run away for shame, Alisander. There, ant shall please you a foolish mild man an honest man, look you, and soon dashed. He is a marvellous good neighbour, faith, and a very good bowler: but, for Alisander,alas, you see how tis,a little oerparted. But there are Worthies acoming will speak their mind in some other sort. Enter HOLOFERNES, for Judas and MOTH, for Hercules
SIR NATHANIEL retires

lines.speaker: holofernes
lines.text: Great Hercules is presented by this imp, Whose club killd Cerberus, that threeheaded canis And when he was a babe, a child, a shrimp, Thus did he strangle serpents in his manus. Quoniam he seemeth in minority, Ergo I come with this apology. Keep some state in thy exit, and vanish. Judas I am,
MOTH retires

lines.speaker: dumain
lines.text: A Judas!

lines.speaker: holofernes
lines.text: Not Iscariot, sir. Judas I am, ycliped Maccabaeus.

lines.speaker: dumain
lines.text: Judas Maccabaeus clipt is plain Judas.

lines.speaker: biron
lines.text: A kissing traitor. How art thou proved Judas

lines.speaker: holofernes
lines.text: Judas I am,

lines.speaker: dumain
lines.text: The more shame for you, Judas.

lines.speaker: holofernes
lines.text: What mean you, sir

lines.speaker: boyet
lines.text: To make Judas hang himself.

lines.speaker: holofernes
lines.text: Begin, sir you are my elder.

lines.speaker: biron
lines.text: Well followed: Judas was hanged on an elder.

lines.speaker: holofernes
lines.text: I will not be put out of countenance.

lines.speaker: biron
lines.text: Because thou hast no face.

lines.speaker: holofernes
lines.text: What is this

lines.speaker: boyet
lines.text: A citternhead.

lines.speaker: dumain
lines.text: The head of a bodkin.

lines.speaker: biron
lines.text: A Deaths face in a ring.

lines.speaker: longaville
lines.text: The face of an old Roman coin, scarce seen.

lines.speaker: boyet
lines.text: The pommel of Caesars falchion.

lines.speaker: dumain
lines.text: The carvedbone face on a flask.

lines.speaker: biron
lines.text: Saint Georges halfcheek in a brooch.

lines.speaker: dumain
lines.text: Ay, and in a brooch of lead.

lines.speaker: biron
lines.text: Ay, and worn in the cap of a toothdrawer. And now forward for we have put thee in countenance.

lines.speaker: holofernes
lines.text: You have put me out of countenance.

lines.speaker: biron
lines.text: False we have given thee faces.

lines.speaker: holofernes
lines.text: But you have outfaced them all.

lines.speaker: biron
lines.text: An thou wert a lion, we would do so.

lines.speaker: boyet
lines.text: Therefore, as he is an ass, let him go. And so adieu, sweet Jude! nay, why dost thou stay

lines.speaker: dumain
lines.text: For the latter end of his name.

lines.speaker: biron
lines.text: For the ass to the Jude give it him:Judas, away!

lines.speaker: holofernes
lines.text: This is not generous, not gentle, not humble.

lines.speaker: boyet
lines.text: A light for Monsieur Judas! it grows dark, he may stumble.
HOLOFERNES retires

lines.speaker: princess
lines.text: Alas, poor Maccabaeus, how hath he been baited!
Enter DON ADRIANO DE ARMADO, for Hector

lines.speaker: biron
lines.text: Hide thy head, Achilles: here comes Hector in arms.

lines.speaker: dumain
lines.text: Though my mocks come home by me, I will now be merry.

lines.speaker: ferdinand
lines.text: Hector was but a Troyan in respect of this.

lines.speaker: boyet
lines.text: But is this Hector

lines.speaker: ferdinand
lines.text: I think Hector was not so cleantimbered.

lines.speaker: longaville
lines.text: His leg is too big for Hectors.

lines.speaker: dumain
lines.text: More calf, certain.

lines.speaker: boyet
lines.text: No he is best endued in the small.

lines.speaker: biron
lines.text: This cannot be Hector.

lines.speaker: dumain
lines.text: Hes a god or a painter for he makes faces. DON

lines.speaker: adriano de armado
lines.text: The armipotent Mars, of lances the almighty, Gave Hector a gift,

lines.speaker: dumain
lines.text: A gilt nutmeg.

lines.speaker: biron
lines.text: A lemon.

lines.speaker: longaville
lines.text: Stuck with cloves.

lines.speaker: dumain
lines.text: No, cloven. DON

lines.speaker: adriano de armado
lines.text: Peace! The armipotent Mars, of lances the almighty Gave Hector a gift, the heir of Ilion A man so breathed, that certain he would fight yea From morn till night, out of his pavilion. I am that flower,

lines.speaker: dumain
lines.text: That mint.

lines.speaker: longaville
lines.text: That columbine. DON

lines.speaker: adriano de armado
lines.text: Sweet Lord Longaville, rein thy tongue.

lines.speaker: longaville
lines.text: I must rather give it the rein, for it runs against Hector.

lines.speaker: dumain
lines.text: Ay, and Hectors a greyhound. DON

lines.speaker: adriano de armado
lines.text: The sweet warman is dead and rotten sweet chucks, beat not the bones of the buried: when he breathed, he was a man. But I will forward with my device. Sweet royalty, bestow on me the sense of hearing.
To the PRINCESS

lines.speaker: princess
lines.text: Speak, brave Hector: we are much delighted. DON

lines.speaker: adriano de armado
lines.text: I do adore thy sweet graces slipper.

lines.speaker: boyet
lines.text: [Aside to DUMAIN]  Loves her by the foot,

lines.speaker: dumain
lines.text: [Aside to BOYET]  He may not by the yard. DON

lines.speaker: adriano de armado
lines.text: This Hector far surmounted Hannibal,

lines.speaker: costard
lines.text: The party is gone, fellow Hector, she is gone she is two months on her way. DON

lines.speaker: adriano de armado
lines.text: What meanest thou

lines.speaker: costard
lines.text: Faith, unless you play the honest Troyan, the poor wench is cast away: shes quick the child brags in her belly already: tis yours. DON

lines.speaker: adriano de armado
lines.text: Dost thou infamonize me among potentates thou shalt die.

lines.speaker: costard
lines.text: Then shall Hector be whipped for Jaquenetta that is quick by him and hanged for Pompey that is dead by him.

lines.speaker: dumain
lines.text: Most rare Pompey!

lines.speaker: boyet
lines.text: Renowned Pompey!

lines.speaker: biron
lines.text: Greater than great, great, great, great Pompey! Pompey the Huge!

lines.speaker: dumain
lines.text: Hector trembles.

lines.speaker: biron
lines.text: Pompey is moved. More Ates, more Ates! stir them on! stir them on!

lines.speaker: dumain
lines.text: Hector will challenge him.

lines.speaker: biron
lines.text: Ay, if a have no mans blood ins belly than will sup a flea. DON

lines.speaker: adriano de armado
lines.text: By the north pole, I do challenge thee.

lines.speaker: costard
lines.text: I will not fight with a pole, like a northern man: Ill slash Ill do it by the sword. I bepray you, let me borrow my arms again.

lines.speaker: dumain
lines.text: Room for the incensed Worthies!

lines.speaker: costard
lines.text: Ill do it in my shirt.

lines.speaker: dumain
lines.text: Most resolute Pompey!

lines.speaker: moth
lines.text: Master, let me take you a buttonhole lower. Do you not see Pompey is uncasing for the combat What mean you You will lose your reputation. DON

lines.speaker: adriano de armado
lines.text: Gentlemen and soldiers, pardon me I will not combat in my shirt.

lines.speaker: dumain
lines.text: You may not deny it: Pompey hath made the challenge. DON

lines.speaker: adriano de armado
lines.text: Sweet bloods, I both may and will.

lines.speaker: biron
lines.text: What reason have you fort DON

lines.speaker: adriano de armado
lines.text: The naked truth of it is, I have no shirt I go woolward for penance.

lines.speaker: boyet
lines.text: True, and it was enjoined him in Rome for want of linen: since when, Ill be sworn, he wore none but a dishclout of Jaquenettas, and that a wears next his heart for a favour.
Enter MERCADE

lines.speaker: mercade
lines.text: God save you, madam!

lines.speaker: princess
lines.text: Welcome, Mercade But that thou interruptst our merriment.

lines.speaker: mercade
lines.text: I am sorry, madam for the news I bring Is heavy in my tongue. The king your father

lines.speaker: princess
lines.text: Dead, for my life!

lines.speaker: mercade
lines.text: Even so my tale is told.

lines.speaker: biron
lines.text: Worthies, away! the scene begins to cloud. DON

lines.speaker: adriano de armado
lines.text: For mine own part, I breathe free breath. I have seen the day of wrong through the little hole of discretion, and I will right myself like a soldier.
Exeunt Worthies

lines.speaker: ferdinand
lines.text: How fares your majesty

lines.speaker: princess
lines.text: Boyet, prepare I will away tonight.

lines.speaker: ferdinand
lines.text: Madam, not so I do beseech you, stay.

lines.speaker: princess
lines.text: Prepare, I say. I thank you, gracious lords, For all your fair endeavors and entreat, Out of a newsad soul, that you vouchsafe In your rich wisdom to excuse or hide The liberal opposition of our spirits, If overboldly we have borne ourselves In the converse of breath: your gentleness Was guilty of it. Farewell worthy lord! A heavy heart bears not a nimble tongue: Excuse me so, coming too short of thanks For my great suit so easily obtaind.

lines.speaker: ferdinand
lines.text: The extreme parts of time extremely forms All causes to the purpose of his speed, And often at his very loose decides That which long process could not arbitrate: And though the mourning brow of progeny Forbid the smiling courtesy of love The holy suit which fain it would convince, Yet, since loves argument was first on foot, Let not the cloud of sorrow justle it From what it purposed since, to wail friends lost Is not by much so wholesomeprofitable As to rejoice at friends but newly found.

lines.speaker: princess
lines.text: I understand you not: my griefs are double.

lines.speaker: biron
lines.text: Honest plain words best pierce the ear of grief And by these badges understand the king. For your fair sakes have we neglected time, Playd foul play with our oaths: your beauty, ladies, Hath much deformd us, fashioning our humours Even to the opposed end of our intents: And what in us hath seemd ridiculous, As love is full of unbefitting strains, All wanton as a child, skipping and vain, Formd by the eye and therefore, like the eye, Full of strange shapes, of habits and of forms, Varying in subjects as the eye doth roll To every varied object in his glance: Which particoated presence of loose love Put on by us, if, in your heavenly eyes, Have misbecomed our oaths and gravities, Those heavenly eyes, that look into these faults, Suggested us to make. Therefore, ladies, Our love being yours, the error that love makes Is likewise yours: we to ourselves prove false, By being once false for ever to be true To those that make us both,fair ladies, you: And even that falsehood, in itself a sin, Thus purifies itself and turns to grace.

lines.speaker: princess
lines.text: We have received your letters full of love Your favours, the ambassadors of love And, in our maiden council, rated them At courtship, pleasant jest and courtesy, As bombast and as lining to the time: But more devout than this in our respects Have we not been and therefore met your loves In their own fashion, like a merriment.

lines.speaker: dumain
lines.text: Our letters, madam, showd much more than jest.

lines.speaker: longaville
lines.text: So did our looks.

lines.speaker: rosaline
lines.text: We did not quote them so.

lines.speaker: ferdinand
lines.text: Now, at the latest minute of the hour, Grant us your loves.

lines.speaker: princess
lines.text: A time, methinks, too short To make a worldwithoutend bargain in. No, no, my lord, your grace is perjured much, Full of dear guiltiness and therefore this: If for my love, as there is no such cause, You will do aught, this shall you do for me: Your oath I will not trust but go with speed To some forlorn and naked hermitage, Remote from all the pleasures of the world There stay until the twelve celestial signs Have brought about the annual reckoning. If this austere insociable life Change not your offer made in heat of blood If frosts and fasts, hard lodging and thin weeds Nip not the gaudy blossoms of your love, But that it bear this trial and last love Then, at the expiration of the year, Come challenge me, challenge me by these deserts, And, by this virgin palm now kissing thine I will be thine and till that instant shut My woeful self up in a mourning house, Raining the tears of lamentation For the remembrance of my fathers death. If this thou do deny, let our hands part, Neither entitled in the others heart.

lines.speaker: ferdinand
lines.text: If this, or more than this, I would deny, To flatter up these powers of mine with rest, The sudden hand of death close up mine eye! Hence ever then my heart is in thy breast.

lines.speaker: dumain
lines.text: But what to me, my love but what to me A wife

lines.speaker: katharine
lines.text: A beard, fair health, and honesty With threefold love I wish you all these three.

lines.speaker: dumain
lines.text: O, shall I say, I thank you, gentle wife

lines.speaker: katharine
lines.text: Not so, my lord a twelvemonth and a day Ill mark no words that smoothfaced wooers say: Come when the king doth to my lady come Then, if I have much love, Ill give you some.

lines.speaker: dumain
lines.text: Ill serve thee true and faithfully till then.

lines.speaker: katharine
lines.text: Yet swear not, lest ye be forsworn again.

lines.speaker: longaville
lines.text: What says Maria

lines.speaker: maria
lines.text: At the twelvemonths end Ill change my black gown for a faithful friend.

lines.speaker: longaville
lines.text: Ill stay with patience but the time is long.

lines.speaker: maria
lines.text: The liker you few taller are so young.

lines.speaker: biron
lines.text: Studies my lady mistress, look on me Behold the window of my heart, mine eye, What humble suit attends thy answer there: Impose some service on me for thy love.

lines.speaker: rosaline
lines.text: Oft have I heard of you, my Lord Biron, Before I saw you and the worlds large tongue Proclaims you for a man replete with mocks, Full of comparisons and wounding flouts, Which you on all estates will execute That lie within the mercy of your wit. To weed this wormwood from your fruitful brain, And therewithal to win me, if you please, Without the which I am not to be won, You shall this twelvemonth term from day to day Visit the speechless sick and still converse With groaning wretches and your task shall be, With all the fierce endeavor of your wit To enforce the pained impotent to smile.

lines.speaker: biron
lines.text: To move wild laughter in the throat of death It cannot be it is impossible: Mirth cannot move a soul in agony.

lines.speaker: rosaline
lines.text: Why, thats the way to choke a gibing spirit, Whose influence is begot of that loose grace Which shallow laughing hearers give to fools: A jests prosperity lies in the ear Of him that hears it, never in the tongue Of him that makes it: then, if sickly ears, Deafd with the clamours of their own dear groans, Will hear your idle scorns, continue then, And I will have you and that fault withal But if they will not, throw away that spirit, And I shall find you empty of that fault, Right joyful of your reformation.

lines.speaker: biron
lines.text: A twelvemonth! well befall what will befall, Ill jest a twelvemonth in an hospital.

lines.speaker: princess
lines.text: [To FERDINAND]  Ay, sweet my lord and so I take my leave.

lines.speaker: ferdinand
lines.text: No, madam we will bring you on your way.

lines.speaker: biron
lines.text: Our wooing doth not end like an old play Jack hath not Jill: these ladies courtesy Might well have made our sport a comedy.

lines.speaker: ferdinand
lines.text: Come, sir, it wants a twelvemonth and a day, And then twill end.

lines.speaker: biron
lines.text: Thats too long for a play. DON
Reenter DON ADRIANO DE ARMADO

lines.speaker: adriano de armado
lines.text: Sweet majesty, vouchsafe me,

lines.speaker: princess
lines.text: Was not that Hector

lines.speaker: dumain
lines.text: The worthy knight of Troy. DON

lines.speaker: adriano de armado
lines.text: I will kiss thy royal finger, and take leave. I am a votary I have vowed to Jaquenetta to hold the plough for her sweet love three years. But, most esteemed greatness, will you hear the dialogue that the two learned men have compiled in praise of the owl and the cuckoo It should have followed in the end of our show.

lines.speaker: ferdinand
lines.text: Call them forth quickly we will do so. DON

lines.speaker: adriano de armado
lines.text: Holla! approach. This side is Hiems, Winter, this Ver, the Spring the one maintained by the owl, the other by the cuckoo. Ver, begin. SPRING. When daisies pied and violets blue And ladysmocks all silverwhite And cuckoobuds of yellow hue Do paint the meadows with delight, The cuckoo then, on every tree, Mocks married men for thus sings he, Cuckoo Cuckoo, cuckoo: O word of fear, Unpleasing to a married ear! When shepherds pipe on oaten straws And merry larks are ploughmens clocks, When turtles tread, and rooks, and daws, And maidens bleach their summer smocks The cuckoo then, on every tree, Mocks married men for thus sings he, Cuckoo Cuckoo, cuckoo: O word of fear, Unpleasing to a married ear! WINTER. When icicles hang by the wall And Dick the shepherd blows his nail And Tom bears logs into the hall And milk comes frozen home in pail, When blood is nippd and ways be foul, Then nightly sings the staring owl, Tuwhit Tuwho, a merry note, While greasy Joan doth keel the pot. When all aloud the wind doth blow And coughing drowns the parsons saw And birds sit brooding in the snow And Marians nose looks red and raw, When roasted crabs hiss in the bowl, Then nightly sings the staring owl, Tuwhit Tuwho, a merry note, While greasy Joan doth keel the pot. DON The words of Mercury are harsh after the songs of Apollo. You that way: we this way.
Reenter HOLOFERNES, SIR NATHANIEL, MOTH, COSTARD, and others
THE SONG
Exeunt
